Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Small-Molecule Capture and Ion Transport in Well-Defined Hybrid Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, this program will design functional organic-inorganic hybrids to combine the advantages of molecules and extended solids in single-phase and well-defined materials. Specific targets include i) nonporous sorbents for the capture of atmospheric pollutants through chemisorption, ii) solid-state reaction templates that can alter product distribution from that of solution-state synthesis, and iii) materials with high ion mobility and tunable ion-transport pathways for fuel cell membranes and solid electrolytes. Solution-state self-assembly routes will be developed to synthesize highly modular structures amenable to systematic material optimization. The substantially different properties of the organic and inorganic components allow for optimization of conflicting features in single-phase materials.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This research program targets the synthesis of organic-inorganic hybrid materials for applications in clean energy: sorbents to capture atmospheric pollutants, nonporous ion-exchange membranes for fuel cells, and solid electrolytes for rechargeable batteries. Most functional materials are plagued by tradeoffs. Optimization of one property requires compromising another: e.g., flexibility and strength, electronic conductivity and porosity. Inorganic solids have superior electronic, thermal, and mechanical properties typically not seen in molecules. However, the tools of synthetic chemistry allow for the structure and reactivity of molecules to be tuned at a level of precision not yet accessible with extended solids. This research seeks to combine the fields of solid-state chemistry and solution-state molecular synthesis to obtain materials with properties unique to both discrete molecules and extended solids.
Many female faculty claim that female colleagues and mentors were instrumental in their career choice, but not all female students have easy access to informal female mentors. As a step towards decreasing the number of exceptional women who leave the academic track, the P.I. will develop an online mentor network. This program will provide interested female students with young female faculty mentors. Through a network of informal mentors, students can have senior colleagues in the community-with whom they identify-who have taken the next steps in the path to their chosen careers and are available for advice and encouragement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded program has developed several research themes based on post-synthetic transformations in solid-state materials. We initially investigated layered halide perovskites: materials with inorganic metal-halide layers partitioned by layers of organic small molecules.  We then expanded our work to cyanide-based coordination networks (Prussian Blue analogs), functionalized carbon, and metallopolymers. Some representative examples are described below.

Sponges are porous, as are most materials developed for gas capture. Our work showed the first examples of reactions between nonporous layered halide perovskites and small molecules. Importantly, this work revealed that porosity was not required for halide perovskites to capture small molecules. We found that these perovskites can expand (like an accordion) to capture gases with record volumetric capacity, with particular utility for the capture of radioactive iodine gas released from nuclear power plants. Here, the organic component of the material captures the radioactive iodine gas while the inorganic component can attenuate the radiation, enabling safer storage. This reactivity was developed further to design halide perovskites that can separate the halogens (e.g., Br2 from I2) in the gas phase. This work also led to our observation that halogen gas can exchange the halides in halide perovskites. Interestingly, the morphology of the parent material (e.g., a uniform film) is retained in the product in this unusual gas-solid reaction. This reaction has potential utility in halide perovskite optoelectronics, where high-quality large-area films are required. 

Our investigations into intercalation chemistry of halide perovskites led us to the first example of electrochemical Li+ cycling in a layered halide perovskite, which can function as an inexpensive Li battery cathode. We also found that intercalating polarizable small molecules in the organic layers of halide perovskites can substantially affect the optoelectronic properties of the inorganic layers by changing the local dielectric constants of the hybrid material. As part of post-synthetic transformations, we have also invested substantial effort on understanding the effects of lattice compression. Halide perovskites are softer and more compressible than oxide perovskites. Our high-pressure diamond-anvil studies of halide perovskites have revealed a large pressure response with dramatic changes in optical and electronic properties. Importantly, these materials remain crystalline even at GPa-scale pressures enabling us to determine the high-pressure structures through X-ray diffraction. We showed that electronic effects (a Jahn-teller distortion of a Cu2+ center) can be partially suppressed with mechanical force, and showed the first example of metallic conductivity in the celebrated semiconductor (CH3NH3)PbI3.

Our post-synthetic investigations have led us to a number of different materials. For example, we showed that high energy density (seen in batteries) and high power density (seen in capacitors) can be achieved in inexpensive carbon black electrodes post synthetically functionalized with organic molecules (quinones). We also found that post-synthetic exposure to oxygen can dramatically increase the electronic conductivity in a porous metal-cyanide framework (Prussian Blue analog) by accessing a mixed-valence material. We also developed cationic metallopolymers, which can be reduced to form neutral mixed-valence polymers with appreciable electronic conductivity. Notably, the anions that leave the cationic polymer when the polymer is reduced templates pores in the neutral polymer. Therefore, reduction of the parent polymer affords a material with substantial electronic conductivity and porosity. We then further developed this polymer to capture toxic NO2 gas. 

We have also written a number of reviews specifically targeting students and young researchers interested in joining this field.

Most undergraduate curricula do not formally introduce undergraduate students to inorganic/solid-state chemistry until after they declare a major. In order to show students the beauty of materials chemistry when they are still deciding on a major, over the past five years the PI has restructured lectures in the standard general chemistry course to incorporate examples from coordination chemistry and solid-state chemistry. (E.g., the crystal structures of battery electrode materials that enable both electronic and ionic motion and what factors dictate the kinetics and thermodynamics of batteries). This effort has launched a new general chemistry course with a greater focus on materials including electronic structure of both molecules and extended solids. Undergraduate students have played an important role in the PI's research group, working on independent research projects, publishing papers, and presenting at conferences. A high-school student started developing a database of crystal structures from our research that we hope to make publicly available. The group is engaged in a number of outreach activities at local high schools to encourage students to explore the Sciences. The group also conducts a biannual class at Stanford University introducing the basics of crystallography and featuring their current research and newly synthesized materials for local students from grades 7 - 12, which has been well received.
